sentences: John Burton Davis Jr. (December 2, 1924 – July 27, 2016) was an American cartoonist and illustrator, known for his advertising art, magazine covers, film posters, record album art and numerous comic book stories.
section: N/A

sentences: He was one of the founding cartoonists for Mad in 1952.
section: N/A

sentences: His cartoon characters are characterized by extremely distorted anatomy, including big heads, skinny legs and large feet.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Davis was born December 2, 1924, in Atlanta, Georgia.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: As a child, he adored listening to Bob Hope on the radio and tried to draw him, despite not knowing what Hope looked like.

section: == Career == | === Early work ===
== Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Davis saw comic book publication at the age of 12 when he contributed a cartoon to the reader's page of Tip Top Comics No. 9 (December 1936).
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: After drawing for his high school newspaper and yearbook, he spent three years in the U.S. Navy, where he contributed to the daily Navy News.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: Attending the University of Georgia on the G.I. Bill, he drew for the campus newspaper and helped launch an off-campus humor publication, Bullsheet, which he described as "not political or anything but just something with risque jokes and cartoons."
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: After graduation, he was a cartoonist intern at The Atlanta Journal, and he worked one summer inking Ed Dodd's Mark Trail comic strip, a strip which he later parodied in Mad as Mark Trade.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: In 1949, he illustrated a Coca-Cola training manual, a job that gave him enough money to buy a car and drive to New York.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: Attending the Art Students League of New York, he found work with the Herald Tribune Syndicate as an inker on Leslie Charteris's The Saint comic strip, drawn by Mike Roy in 1949–1950.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: His own humor strip, Beauregard, with gags in a Civil War setting, was carried briefly by the McClure Syndicate.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: After rejections from several comic book publishers, he began freelancing for William Gaines' EC Comics in 1950, contributing to Tales from the Crypt, The Vault of Horror, The Haunt of Fear, Frontline Combat, Two-Fisted Tales, Piracy, Incredible Science Fiction, Crime Suspenstories, Shock Suspenstories and Terror Illustrated.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: In 2011, Davis told The Wall Street Journal about his early career and his breakthrough with EC:
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: I was about ready to give up, go home to Georgia and be either a forest ranger or a farmer.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: But I went down to Canal Street and Lafayette, up in an old rickety elevator and through a glass door to Entertaining Comics where Al Feldstein and Bill Gaines were putting out horror [comic] books.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: They looked at my work and it was horrible and they gave me a job right away!
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: Every time you went in to see Bill Gaines, he would write you a check when you brought in a story.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: You didn't have to put in a bill or anything.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: I was very, very hungry and I was thinking about getting married.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: So I kept the road pretty hot between home and Canal Street.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: I would go in for that almighty check, go home and do the work, bring it in and get another check and pick up another story.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: [Edit: the actual cross street to Lafayette was Spring Street, not Canal.]
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: Davis was particularly noted for his depiction of the Crypt-Keeper in the horror comics, revamping the character's appearance from the more simplistic Al Feldstein version to a tougher, craggier, mangier man with hairy warts, salivating mouth and oversized hands and feet, who usually did not wear shoes.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: Among the classic horror tales he illustrated were "Foul Play", which was cited in Dr. Fredric Wertham's book Seduction of the Innocent for its depiction of "a comic book baseball game".
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: Others, like "Tain't the Meat, It's the Humanity", "Death of Some Salesman", "Fare Tonight Followed by Increasing Clottiness", "Tight Grip" and "Lower Berth", were Crypt-Keeper classics.

sentences: He did the covers for every issue of Crypt from issue No. 29 to No. 46.

sentences: In his work for Harvey Kurtzman's war comics, he tackled a variety of subjects and had a particular affinity for depicting American Civil War stories.

sentences: He also did many covers for Frontline Combat, Two-Fisted Tales and Incredible Science Fiction as well.

sentences: The editors, William M. Gaines, Albert B. Feldstein and Harvey Kurtzman, have said he was the fastest artist they had in those days, completely penciling and inking three or more pages a day at times.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: His use of the brush to create depth and mood was unique and memorable.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: His wrinkled clothing, scratchy lines, and multi-layered layouts were so popular in the 1950s that other artists at rival companies began copying the style—notably, Howard Nostrand in Harvey's horror comics.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: In the late 1950s, Davis drew Western stories for Atlas Comics.

sentences: His 1963 work on the Rawhide Kid (#33–35) was his last for non-humor comic books.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: His style of wild, free-flowing brushwork and wacky characters made him a perfect choice when Harvey Kurtzman launched Mad as a zany, satirical EC comic book in 1952.

sentences: He appeared in most of the first 30 issues of Mad, all 12 issues of Panic and even some work in Cracked.

sentences: Davis contributed to other Kurtzman magazines—Trump, Humbug and Help!—eventually expanding into illustrations for record jackets, movie posters, books and magazines, including Time and TV Guide.

== Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Advertising and magazines
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===
== Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Davis first worked with TV Guide in 1965, which hired him to illustrate an expansive eight-page advertising supplement for NBC's TV lineup, which featured icons such as Johnny Carson, Dean Martin and fictional characters such as Dr. Kildare, Napoleon Solo and Maxwell Smart.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: His first cover for the magazine came in 1968, when he depicted a tribute to Andy Griffith, in which the actor was hoisted on the shoulders of his costars, Don Knotts and Jim Nabors.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Davis recalls, "Every assignment was a thrill because TV Guide was the top magazine in the country.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: I couldn't wait to get in my little MG and drive from New York out to the magazine's offices in Radnor, Pennsylvania, to show the editors my latest design.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: I felt like the luckiest guy in the world."
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Davis would contribute 23 covers for TV Guide between 1968 and 1981.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: In 2013 the magazine honored him in a retrospective in which it recounted his history with the publication and spotlighted some of his most memorable covers, including those depicting Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In (March 28, 1970), Davis' childhood hero Bob Hope for a cover on Hope's history with the Oscars (April 10, 1971) and Bonanza (August 14, 1971).
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Years later, while watching a TV interview of Hope, Davis was gratified to notice that his Hope cover was displayed on the back wall of the comedian's office; "it was one of the proudest moments of my life," recalled Davis.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Davis created the cartoon bee which (in decal form) appears on the flanks of all the buses in the Bee-Line running from Westchester to New York City.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: A Westchester resident at the time, Davis lived directly adjacent to one of the Bee Line's bus routes, and he mentioned in an interview how gratifying it was to see his own artwork drive past his window several times every day.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Similar synchronicity happened when Mad moved to 1700 Broadway, where the magazine's fifth-floor production department was next to a wall three feet away that had previously been the location of an immense Davis cartoon for a bank, an advertisement that towered six stories over 53rd Street.

== Personal life and death ==

sentences: Personal life and death ==
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Davis grew up and went to college in Georgia.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Following his professional career in New York, Davis and his wife Dena moved to St. Simons Island, Georgia in the 1990s.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: They raised two children: daughter Katie Davis Lloyd and son Jack Davis III, who gave the cause of his father's death on July 27, 2016 at age 91 as complications from a stroke.
section: == Personal life and death ==
== Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: Awards and exhibitions ==
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: Davis was inducted into the Will Eisner Hall of Fame in 2003.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: He also received the National Cartoonists Society's Milton Caniff Lifetime Achievement Award in 1996.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: A finalist for inclusion in the Jack Kirby Hall of Fame in 1990, 1991 and 1992, he received the National Cartoonists Society's Advertising Award for 1980 and their Reuben Award for 2000.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: He was award the Inkpot Award in 1985.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: In June 2002, Davis had a retrospective exhibition of his work at the Society of Illustrators in New York.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: He was inducted into the Society of Illustrators Hall of Fame in 2005.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: In 1989, Davis was commissioned by the United States Postal Service to design the 25-cent Letter Carriers stamp.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: There was some concern that the cartoon would offend some letter carriers as being too informal and not respectful of their position.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: However, the president of the Letter Carriers Union gave his blessing, and the stamp was well received.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: Although postal policy does not allow artists to portray living persons on stamps, one of the carriers in the stamp is an unmistakable self-portrait of Davis.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: In 2019, Davis was posthumously awarded the Inkwell Awards Stacey Aragon Special Recognition Award for his lifetime of work in the inking field.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==
